citations.narrative:
The facility has not updated their disposition records for three goats donated since their last inspection. Complete and
accurate acquisition and disposition records, including offspring born at the facility, records must be kept to allow for
accurate identification and medical care of the animals, as well as lawful tracking of their movement.
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and
disposition information. This information must include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were
acquired, the USDA license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license
number and state if not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of
acquisition or disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved.

The facility has not conducted an annual review of their contingency plan. Reviewing the outlined plan in place ensures
the facility has assessed the current plan for any needed amendments to better prepare for unexpected disasters or
events, as well as a detailed strategy to address instructions for, but not limited to: animal evacuation, sheltering-in-place,
and backup provisions for husbandry and food/watering supplies, sanitation, and ventilation. The facility shall develop and
document an appropriate contingency plan available for review upon USDA inspections.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 20, 2026, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
End Section

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility has not updated their disposition records for three goats donated since their last inspection. Complete and 
accurate acquisition and disposition records, including offspring born at the facility, records must be kept to allow for 
accurate identification and medical care of the animals, as well as lawful tracking of their movement.  
The facility shall make, keep and maintain records that fully and correctly include all the required acquisition and 
disposition information. This information must include the name and address of the person from whom the animals were 
acquired, the USDA license number of the person if licensed or the vehicle license number and state and driver’s license 
number and state if not licensed, the name and address of the person to whom an animal was given/sold, the date of 
acquisition or disposition, the species of animal and the number of animals involved. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The facility has not conducted an annual review of their contingency plan. Reviewing the outlined plan in place ensures 
the facility has assessed the current plan for any needed amendments to better prepare for unexpected disasters or 
events, as well as a detailed strategy to address instructions for, but not limited to: animal evacuation, sheltering-in-place, 
and backup provisions for husbandry and food/watering supplies, sanitation, and ventilation. The facility shall develop and 
document an appropriate contingency plan available for review upon USDA inspections. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 20, 2026, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

End Section

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
